poem:
**Garden Reverie**

In the quiet persistence of the garden,  
a bulb lasagne simmers beneath the soil,  
layered secrets waiting to unfurl,  
like thoughts we tend and trim.  

Ella Malt speaks in whispers:  
don't rip—observe,  
embrace the slow alchemy of leaves  
and the promise of edges  
crafted with care,  
where beauty waits,  
gentle and ready.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Buy small plants – and consider a ‘bulb lasagne’: how to give your garden a late-summer glow-up Clear and cut back “It is not always necessary to rip out everything and start again,” says Ella Malt, who runs the gardening company Soil and Soul Norfolk. “It is much more sustainable to work with what you have. You can make such a difference with a bit of cutting back, clearing up leaves, cutting an edge on". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
